questions.text: A 60-year-old man, with a history of myocardial infarction 1 year back, presents with complaints of palpitations and syncope. The ECG strip obtained during his admission is given below. What is the long-term treatment for this condition?
questions.solution:
In the given ECG, the PR segment remains the same in each successive cycle. However, some P waves are not followed by QRS complexes, which means that some of the P waves are not conducted due to an atrioventricular conduction block. This is typical of Mobitz type II block. The definitive long-term treatment is, therefore, a permanent pacemaker. 

This patient with a history of ischemic heart disease (previous history of inferior-wall MI) and signs of acquired Mobitz type II AV block will benefit most from a permanent pacemaker and it is recommended regardless of symptoms.

In the ECG below, the blue arrows show P waves, and the last P wave is not followed by a QRS complex. This missed QRS complex is marked by the red arrow. Mobitz type II is often a problem in the infra-nodal conduction system, and therefore, is associated with wide QRS complexes (in leads V1, V2, and V3 of the given ECG), as indicated by the red box.

Other options:

Option A - Amiodarone, a class III anti-arrhythmic agent, is the drug of choice in the acute treatment as well as prevention of ventricular tachycardia and ventricular fibrillation. It is a rate-control medication. 

Options B and D - Pharmacologic interventions such as atropine and isoproterenol serve as short-term supplementary treatment options until a pacemaker can be installed or if the AV block is transient in nature. Even in such instances, a temporary transcutaneous pacemaker is preferred until a permanent device is available. 

Related Pearl: Indication for Pacemaker in AV Conduction Defects

  • In any patient with symptomatic bradycardia
  • Irreversible second- or third-degree AV bloc
  • Pacing in patients with asymptomatic AV block should be individualized

With acquired CHB

Left ventricular dysfunction and

Waking heart rates 40 beats/min.
  • Asymptomatic second-degree AV block of either type, if the block is demonstrated to be intra- or infra-His or is associated with a wide QRS complex
  • Neuromuscular diseases having a predilection for the conduction system, such as myotonic dystrophy and other muscular dystrophies, and Kearns-Sayre syndrome

Related Pearl: Types of Heart block

questions.text: A hypertensive patient was brought to the emergency due to complaints of palpitations and breathing difficulty. Comment on his ECG.
questions.solution:
The above ECG shows a pattern of premature ventricular contractions, one premature beat after one normal beat. This is seen in ventricular bigeminy.

Premature ventricular contractions/beats (PVC) are single ventricular beats that occur earlier than the next normal supraventricular beat. They originate from abnormal foci in the ventricular tissue:

  • Unifocal PVCs arise from a single focus and hence have the same QRS morphology
  • Multifocal PVCs arise from multiple foci and therefore have different QRS morphologies

They are not preceded by a P wave as they do not originate in the atria. They show wide QRS complexes (>0.12 ms) on the ECG because they are conducted via normal myocardial tissue instead of the Purkinje system.

Ventricular bigeminy refers to a pair of normal and premature ventricular contractions, whereas ventricular trigeminy refers to a premature beat that occurs after two normal beats. Quadrigeminy is when a premature beat follows three normal beats.

Few other terms associated with premature ventricular contractions:

  • Two successive PVCs are known as a couplet
  • Three successive PVCs are known as a triplet.

The given ECG shows ventricular bigeminy with premature beats circled in red and normal ventricular contractions circled in green.

questions.text: A 72-year-old man comes to the emergency room complaining his heart is pounding and that he is going to die. The emergency physician orders an ECG. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given ECG shows ST elevation in leads V1-V4 which is suggestive of acute anteroseptal myocardial infarction (MI). ST depression in the leads III and aVF signifies an old inferior wall infarction.

Related Pearl: Localisation of MI based on ST elevations in different leads

Extensive anterior - I, aVL, V1-V6

Lateral - I, aVL

Inferior - II, III, aVF

Anteroseptal - V1-V4

Anterolateral - I, aVL, V3-V6

Posterior - ST depression and tall R in V1-V4

questions.text: A 68-year-old male admitted to the ICU for acute exacerbation of COPD develops a sudden onset of palpitations. The following ECG changes are seen. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a COPD patient in ICU developing palpitations and the ECG showing narrow QRS complex (<0.12 s) tachycardia with more than three different P wave morphologies, points to the diagnosis of multifocal atrial tachycardia (MAT).

Multifocal atrial tachycardia (MAT) is characterized by at least 3 distinct P wave morphologies (shown by arrows in the image) with rates typically between 100 and 150 beats/min.

It is usually encountered in patients with chronic pulmonary disease and acute illness. The clinical features are most commonly related to the underlying precipitating illness (COPD in this case). Unlike atrial fibrillation, there are clear isoelectric intervals between P waves.

Treating the underlying disease and correcting any metabolic abnormalities is the mainstay of treatment. Electrical cardioversion has no effect.

The calcium-channel blockers verapamil or diltiazem may slow the atrial and ventricular rate. MAT may respond to amiodarone, but long-term therapy with this agent is usually avoided due to its toxicities, particularly in pulmonary fibrosis.

Related Pearl: Supraventricular tachycardias

 

Supraventricular tachycardias with narrow QRS complex:

  • Narrow QRS with regular RR interval
   Tachycardia                ECG features
Sinus tachycardia Normal P wave, normal ECG features except for the rate
Focal atrial tachycardia A single type of abnormal p wave morphology is seen
Junctional tachycardia No p waves. Heart rate is 100- 200/ min
AV nodal reentry tachycardia No p waves. Pseudo R' waves may be seen. Heart rate is 150-250/ min
Atrioventricular reentry tachycardia P wave always follows QRS. RP interval< PR interval
Atrial flutter Sawtooth shaped flutter waves are seen

 

  • Narrow QRS with irregular RR interval
     Tachycardia        ECG features
Atrial fibrillation No distinct p waves seen
Multifocal atrial tachycardia More than 3 different abnormal p wave morphologies are seen
Atrial flutter/tachycardia with variable block ECG features of heart block are seen.

  • Antidromic AVRT (atrioventricular reentry tachycardia)
  • Supraventricular tachycardias with bundle branch block

questions.text: A 40-year-old female patient came with complaints of chest pain, palpitation, and shortness of breath. On examination, a mid-diastolic murmur was heard, and a prominent 'a' wave was found on JVP. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The presence of a mid-diastolic murmur and a prominent a-wave in JVP is suggestive of tricuspid stenosis.

Mid-diastolic murmurs result from obstruction and/or augmented flow at the level of the mitral or tricuspid valve. Thus, both mitral stenosis (MS) and tricuspid stenosis (TS) present with a mid-diastolic murmur. However, the presence of a prominent a-wave in JVP points toward tricuspid stenosis.

Causes for mid-diastolic murmur:

  1. Mitral stenosis
  2. Tricuspid stenosis
  3. Atrial myxomas
  4. Austin Flint murmur in severe aortic regurgitation
  5. Carey-Coombs murmur in acute rheumatic fever

Tricuspid stenosis:

It always occurs in association with MS and is rheumatic in origin. Mid-diastolic murmur in TS is best heard along the left sternal border and over the xiphoid process. Murmur is augmented during inspiration and reduced during expiration. The jugular veins are distended, and a giant a-wave is seen in JVP. There is a slow y descent due to impedance of right atrial emptying during diastole. ECG shows features of right atrial enlargement, which includes tall, peaked P wave in lead II and a prominent, upright P wave in lead V1.

Other options:

Option A: Mid-diastolic murmur is seen in mitral stenosis (MS). It occurs most commonly in rheumatic fever. Loud S1 (first heart sound) with an opening snap and a following S2 (second heart sound) is heard. S2 is followed by a low-pitched, rumbling, mid-diastolic murmur, which is best heard at the apex with the patient in a lateral recumbent position. 

Option C: Holosystolic murmur is seen in mitral regurgitation (MR). The major causes of MR are infective endocarditis, myocardial infarction, rheumatic fever, and cardiomyopathies. Soft S1 with a widely split S2 and a low-pitched S3 (third heart sound) is heard in MR. In addition, a holosystolic murmur is prominent at the apex and radiates to the axilla.

Option D: Holosystolic murmur is seen in tricuspid regurgitation (TR). TR is most commonly due to functional defects such as tricuspid annular dilatation and leaflet tethering caused by rheumatic heart disease, myocardial infarction, etc. The jugular vein is distended. Prominent c-v waves and rapid y descents are seen in severe TR. A blowing holosystolic murmur along the lower left sternal margin, which is augmented during inspiration (Carvallo's sign) and reduced during expiration is seen in TR.

Related Pearl: JVP waveform and the abnormalities

1) The a-wave corresponds to atrial contraction.

Abnormality Conditions
Prominent a-waves Pulmonary hypertension, right atrial thrombus/ mass, and tricuspid stenosis
Cannon a-waves

Complete AV block, ventricular tachycardia, and premature atrial/ junctional/ ventricular beats
Absent a-waves Atrial fibrillation

 

2) The c-wave corresponds to the bulging of tricuspid valve into right atrium during ventricular contraction.

 

3) The x-descent corresponds to atrial relaxation during atrial diastole.

Abnormality Conditions
Absent x-descent Severe tricuspid regurgitation
Rapid x-descent Cardiac tamponade

 

4) The v-wave corresponds to the venous filling of right atrium.

Abnormality Conditions
Dominant v-waves Tricuspid regurgitation

 

5) The y-descent corresponds to the passive emptying of the right atrium into right ventricle.

Abnormality Conditions
Prolonged y-descent Tricuspid stenosis
Rapid y-descent

Constrictive pericarditis and isolated severe tricuspid regurgitation

Related Pearl: The causes of holosystolic murmur are:

  • Beat heard over left 3rd and 4th intercostal space
  • Radiates widely
  • Palpable thrill present
  • Decreases in intensity with amyl nitrate
  • Wide splitting of S2 seen

questions.text: A 50 year old male presents to the OPD with chest pain, palpitations and shortness of breath. An ECG is taken to determine the cause of his symptoms. What does the ECG show?
questions.solution:
The ECG shows right ventricular hypertrophy.

ECG findings suggestive of RVH

  • R-V1 >= 7
  • R-V1 + S-V5/V6 > 11
  • Right axis deviation of +110° or more
  • T wave inversion in RV leads (Lead III, V1 & V2)

Causes of RVH

  • Pulmonary hypertension
  • Mitral stenosis
  • Pulmonary embolism
  • Chronic lung disease (Cor pulmonale)
  • Congenital heart disease (e.g. Tetralogy of Fallot, pulmonary stenosis)
  • Arrhythmogenic right ventricular cardiomyopathy

questions.text: A 50-year-old man presents with complaints of breathlessness on walking a few yards. He adds that he has an uncomfortable awareness of his heartbeat, especially on lying down. Examination reveals widened pulse pressure and pulsating uvula. Which of the following would be the most likely auscultatory finding in this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical presentation of breathlessness and palpitations, along with the findings of widened pulse pressure and pulsating uvula, is suggestive of aortic regurgitation(AR). The most likely auscultatory finding in this patient is Austin-Flint murmur.

Aortic regurgitation may either be caused due to valvular heart diseases like endocarditis and rheumatic fever; diseases of the aortic root, like aortic dissection and medial degeneration, or a combination of both.

Men are more commonly affected than women. Patients present with features of an uncomfortable awareness of the heartbeat, especially on lying down, and exertional dyspnea.

The dyspnea is followed by orthopnea, paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea, and excessive diaphoresis. Anginal chest pain may occur, both at rest as well as during exertion; these episodes of chest pain can be prolonged and often do not respond well to sublingual nitroglycerin.

Auscultatory findings in aortic regurgitation include a diastolic murmur and Austin Flint murmur. The former is a typically high-pitched, blowing, decrescendo murmur. It is called a 'cooing dove' murmur when the murmur is of musical quality. Its presence usually signifies the eversion or perforation of an aortic cusp. 

An Austin Flint murmur is a soft, low-pitched, rumbling mid-to-late diastolic murmur. It is created by the regurgitant stream displacing the anterior leaflet of the normal mitral valve.

Other options:

Options B and D: Opening snap and Graham Steel murmur are seen in mitral stenosis. The Graham Steel murmur is a decrescendo diastolic murmur seen in mitral stenosis patients who have developed pulmonary hypertension, and resultant pulmonary regurgitation.

Option C: Gallavardin phenomenon is seen in aortic stenosis, where the coarse systolic murmur of aortic stenosis may sound higher pitched and more acoustically pure at the apex.

questions.text: ECG of a patient who presented with palpitations to the ER is shown below. Which of the following is a likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above ECG shows increased heart rate with wide QRS complexes (> 0.12s). This is suggestive of ventricular tachycardia (VT). 

Types of ventricular tachycardia based on QRS morphology:

  • Monomorphic- a stable QRS morphology from beat to beat
  • Polymorphic- changing or multiform QRS variance from beat to beat. Torsades de pointes is an example of polymorphic ventricular tachycardia.
  • Bidirectional- has a beat-to-beat alternation in the QRS frontal plane axis. It is associated with digitalis toxicity or catecholaminergic polymorphic VT.

The most common cause of VT is ischemic heart disease.

Ventricular tachyarrhythmias occur due to impulses that originate within the ventricles. These impulses are conducted through the normal ventricular myocardial cells instead of the fast conducting Purkinje system. Hence, they present with wide QRS complexes ( >0.12 sec) on the ECG.

Supraventricular tachyarrhythmias occur due to impulses originating above the ventricles. These impulses reach the ventricles through the proper fast conduction pathway resulting in a narrow QRS complex. SVTs are associated with wide QRS in few exceptional conditions like:

  • Conduction block in the left or right bundle branch
  • Activation of ventricles from an accessory pathway- antidromic AVRT

The given ECG shows wide stable QRS complexes in monomorphic ventricular tachycardia:

questions.text: A concerned wife brought her 43-year-old husband to the clinic after an episode of light-headedness and palpitations. An ECG was taken. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient has symptoms and ECG findings suggestive of Mobitz type I or Wenckebach block.

In the given ECG PR segment progressively increases in each successive cycle, until a P wave of the series fails to produce a QRS complex (dropped QRS). In this example, for every 5 'P' waves, there are only 4 'QRS' complexes; hence, this is a 5:4 Wenckebach block.

Related Pearl: Types of Heart block

questions.text: A patient with mitral stenosis presented with worsening dyspnea and fatigue, which are now present at rest. He also complained of a heavy pounding sensation in the chest with recurrent chest pain. You decided to evaluate the patient using echocardiography. When would you advise the patient to undergo a valvotomy?

choices.text: Mitral orifice is <1.5 sq cm with significant regurgitation

questions.solution:
Mitral valvotomy is indicated in symptomatic (NYHA Functional Class II-IV) patients with mitral stenosis (MS) with orifice of <1.5 cm2 in normal-sized adults or <1 cm2/m2 body surface area.

Treatment of mitral stenosis:

  • Administration of warfarin in patients with MS who develop atrial fibrillation.
  • Surgical treatment:
    • Mitral valvotomy: It is done in symptomatic patients whose mitral orifice is less than 1.5 cm2. This can be either percutaneous mitral valvotomy or open surgical valvotomy.
    • Mitral valve replacement: This is done in patients whose mitral valve is severely distorted and associated with significant mitral regurgitation.

Mitral stenosis is a valvular heart disease, most commonly caused by rheumatic fever. Other causes include congenital defects like cor triatriatum and parachute valve, mitral annular calcification with leaflet involvement, infective endocarditis with large vegetations and left atrial myxomas.

Patients present with dyspnea, cough, orthopnea, paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea, and hemoptysis. 

In a normal mitral valve, there is no obstruction to the flow of blood from the left atrium (LA) to the left ventricle. Therefore a small LA pressure is sufficient to empty the blood into the ventricle.

When the MVA is <~2 cm2, blood flows from the LA to the left ventricle, propelled by mildly elevated atrial pressure. Hence, patients are usually asymptomatic and may develop dyspnea only when the heart rate increases, as seen in exertion, excitement, fever, etc.

questions.text: A female patient complains of palpitations and weight loss. Laboratory evaluation shows thyroid-receptor antibody. Which of the following statements is not true about this patient's condition?

choices.text: Associated with enlargement of extraocular muscles

questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of Graves' disease. Radionuclide scan shows increased uptake with diffuse distribution in Graves' disease.

The hyperthyroidism of Graves’ disease is due to the presence of thyroid-stimulating immunoglobulins (TSI). These are synthesized by lymphocytes present in the thyroid gland, as well as in bone marrow and lymph nodes. TSI include TSH receptor antibodies (TRAb), which act on the TSH receptors and stimulate the thyroid gland to produce and release more thyroid hormones, T3 and T4. Feedback inhibition by thyroid hormones causes TSH levels to be suppressed (option D).

Patients present with features of hyperthyroidism like hyperactivity, irritability, heat intolerance, sweating, and palpitations. Diarrhea, weight loss despite increased appetite, and oligomenorrhea are also seen. On examination, tremors and proximal muscle weakness might be seen. Pretibial myxedema (option A) refers to the noninflamed indurated plaque, pink-purple in color, which is seen most commonly on the skin of the anterior aspect of the leg. Thyroid acropachy is a form of clubbing of the fingers. Both these features are relatively specific to Graves' disease but are not seen in all the patients.

Graves ophthalmopathy occurs due to increased volume of the retroorbital connective tissues and extraocular muscles (option B) due to marked lymphocytic infiltration of the retro-orbital space, accumulation of hydrophilic glycosaminoglycans such as hyaluronic acid and chondroitin sulfate, and increased numbers of adipocytes. Early signs of Graves' ophthalmopathy include lid retraction and lid lag on downgaze. Later, the patients develop proptosis, diplopia, corneal damage (due to proptosis), and optic nerve compression causing permanent vision loss. 

The diagnosis of Graves' disease is established by measuring TSH levels (will be suppressed) and T3/T4 levels (will be elevated). Measurement of TRAb is required if the diagnosis is unclear. Radionuclide scan shows diffusely increased uptake in cases of Graves' disease. 

Treatment of Graves' disease includes:

  • Anti-thyroid drugs such as propylthiouracil, carbimazole, and methimazole. Propylthiouracil is the preferred anti-thyroid drug during pregnancy especially till 14-16 weeks, because carbimazole and methimazole are associated with aplasia cutis (absence of skin, usually on the scalp). 
  • Propranolol is given to control adrenergic effects before the effect of anti-thyroid drugs takes effect fully.
  • Radioiodine ablation can be used as a first-line modality, or can be used for patients who have relapsed despite taking anti-thyroid drugs. Pregnancy and breastfeeding are absolute contraindications for radioiodine ablation. 
  • Total thyroidectomy is done for patients who have relapsed despite taking anti-thyroid drugs and prefer surgical treatment over radioiodine ablation.

questions.text: A 68-year-old patient with chronic kidney disease suddenly develops chest pain and palpitations. ECG of the patient is shown below. What is the immediate management of this condition?

choices.text: Administer intravenous regular Insulin with dextrose

questions.solution:
A chronic kidney disease (CKD) patient with chest pain, palpitations, and ECG showing tall, peaked T waves and loss of P waves indicates that the patient is suffering from hyperkalemia. The immediate management is to administer intravenous calcium gluconate which raises the threshold and reduces excitability.

Hyperkalemia is defined as a serum potassium level of more than 5.5 mEq/L. 

The ECG changes that can be seen in hyperkalemia depend on the extent of hyperkalemia. 

Serum potassium level ECG change
5.5 - 6.5 mEq/L tall, peaked T waves with 'tented' or 'pinched' shape
6.5 - 7.5 mEq/L loss of P waves
7.0 - 8.0 mEq/L widened QRS complex
> 8.0 mEq/L sine wave

The most common cause of hyperkalemia is kidney failure. Drugs that cause hyperkalemia include angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors, angiotensin receptor blockers, potassium-sparing diuretics. 

Treatment of hyperkalemia involves the following:

  1. Administer intravenous calcium gluconate which raises the threshold and reduces excitability. It is cardioprotective
  2. Administer regular insulin with dextrose. The insulin will reduce the serum potassium concentration by causing an intracellular shift. The dextrose will counteract the hypoglycemic effects of insulin.
  3. Salbutamol nebulization will also shift potassium inside the cell.
  4. Remove potassium with calcium-based resins, diuretics, or hemodialysis.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man presented with a sensation of rapid heartbeat, increased sweating, and dizziness. The ECG obtained is shown below. His BP is 126/82 mm of Hg. After failed attempts of maintenance with vagal maneuvers, what would be your treatment option?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the ECG showing narrow QRS complexes without P waves and pseudo R waves in aVR lead suggest paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia (PSVT). Intravenous adenosine is preferred for the termination of arrhythmia in stable patients (blood pressure is normal) with regular, narrow complex PSVT. It is given rapidly in a dosage of 6-12 mg. It successfully terminates the arrhythmia (within 1 minute) in more than 90% of the cases.

Adverse effects of adenosine:

  • Transient chest pain
  • Dyspnea
  • Anxiety
  • Precipitates atrial fibrillation (AF)
  • May aggravate bronchospasm

Contraindications of the use of adenosine include patients with prior cardiac transplants since they have potential hypersensitivity due to surgical sympathetic denervation.

It should be cautiously used in patients with Wolff-Parkinson-White syndrome due to the precipitation of atrial fibrillation leading to hemodynamic instability.

When the patient is hemodynamically unstable, i.e. when the patient has hypotension with unconsciousness or respiratory distress, QRS-synchronous direct current cardioversion is done.

questions.text: A patient presented with palpitations and light-headedness. His ECG is shown below. Which of the following drugs is least likely to cause this condition?
questions.solution:
The given scenario and the ECG findings (rapid asynchronous complexes and an undulating baseline) point towards a diagnosis of torsades de pointes. Lidocaine use is unlikely to cause this condition.

Lidocaine belongs to class IB antiarrhythmics. It is considered to have the least arrhythmogenic potential among antiarrhythmics.

Among the antiarrhythmics, class Ia and class III drugs prolong action potential duration and thus prolong QT interval. They are also prone to cause torsades de pointes.

questions.text: A 40-year-old patient complains of palpitations. He is hemodynamically stable. An ECG is obtained and is given below. Which of the following is the most appropriate management?
questions.solution:
The given ECG shows wide complex tachycardia (QRS complexes are >120 ms in duration), with regular QRS complexes with uniform morphology in each lead. This is suggestive of ventricular tachycardia (VT). Since this patient is hemodynamically stable, the best management is IV amiodarone. 

In patients with sustained VT who are hemodynamically stable, medical treatment with intravenous amiodarone is preferred. Alternative drugs that can be given are lignocaine and procainamide. However, if the VT fails to resolve with medical management or if the patient's symptoms worsen, DC cardioversion is the next step. 

Other options:

Option A: Carotid massage has no role in the management of VT. It is used as an initial step in paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia to block the AV node and terminate the arrhythmia.

Option B: Chest compressions are done until the defibrillator is arranged to ensure some amount of cardiac output even during this period.

Option C: If a patient with VT has hemodynamic compromise due to hypotension or impaired consciousness or has pulmonary, electrical cardioversion is performed.

questions.text:
A young girl complains that she suddenly starts feeling intense fear thinking about her exam. During the episode, she can feel her heart beating very rapidly, her hands will be shaking and she has difficulty in breathing. She feels that she might have a heart attack. This usually occurs before her exams. Which of the following drugs can be used in the treatment of this condition?
  1. Alprazolam
  2. Viloxazine
  3. Paroxetine
  4. Clomipramine
  5. Rufinamide
questions.solution:
The clinical features are suggestive of panic disorder. Alprazolam, Paroxetine and Clomipramine are useful in the treatment of this condition.

Panic disorder

It is characterized by the presence of an abrupt surge of intense fear or intense discomfort that reaches a peak within minutes. During the episode, the person may experience:

  • Palpitations
  • Sweating
  • Trembling or shaking
  • Sensations, of shortness of breath
  • Nausea
  • Dizziness
  • Chest pain or discomfort
  • Chills or heat sensations
  • Paresthesias
  • Fear of dying

The patient also might feel like losing control, having a heart attack, or going crazy. 

It is not attributable to any drug abuse, medication, or medical condition.

Important drugs that can be used in the management of this condition are

  • Benzodiazepines- Alprazolam, lorazepam, clonazepam, etc
  • Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors SSRI- Paroxetine, citalopram, escitalopram, fluvoxamine, and sertraline 
  • Tricyclic antidepressants- Clomipramine, imipramine, desipramine
  • Monoamine oxidase inhibitors- Phenelzine, tranylcypromine 

Note- Viloxazine is recently approved for the treatment of attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHA).

Rufinamide is an antiepileptic drug used in the treatment of Lennox- Gastaut syndrome.

  • Worry about an additional panic attack or consequences
  • Changes in behaviour related to attacks (ex: avoidance)

3. Panic attack not attributable to substance abuse or another medical condition.

4. Panic attack not explained by another mental disorder.

Treatment of Panic disorder:

Immediate: Benzodiazepines
Long term: SSRI/ SNRI and or cognitive behavioural therapy

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman comes to the clinic with complaints of recurrent palpitation and lightheadedness. An ECG was taken and is as shown below. What is the best step in management?
questions.solution:
The ECG shows the presence of delta waves (preexcitation wave), wide QRS, and short PR interval which are classically seen in Wolff Parkinson White (WPW) syndrome. In this patient, catheter ablation is the best for long-term management. 

Patients with preexcitation who have symptoms of arrhythmia are at risk for developing AF and sudden death if they have an accessory pathway that allows rapid antegrade conduction (preexcitation & tachyarrhythmias are features of WPW syndrome due to the abnormal accessory pathway).

Complications of catheter ablation are rare but include AV block, cardiac tamponade, thromboembolic events, and hematoma at the access site.

Related Pearl: Wolff Parkinson White Syndrome

Wolff Parkinson White Syndrome (WPW) is characterized by an abnormal accessory pathway in the heart leading to arrhythmias.

Pathology- Born with an accessory pathway, the bundle of Kent which connects the atria and ventricle. The electrical impulses from the SA node reach the ventricles earlier via the accessory pathway as there is no AV nodal delay in this pathway. This leads to the preexcitation of the ventricle and initiation of ventricular contraction. This ventricular contraction is prolonged when the impulse via the AV nodal pathway reaches the ventricles.

Most common location of the accessory pathway- between the left atrium and free wall of the left ventricle

ECG changes:

Shortened PR interval- because of the early initiation of ventricular depolarization

Prolonged QRS duration- because of the AV nodal impulse reaching the ventricles after the aberrant impulse.

Delta waves- slurred upstroke of QRS complex

The given ECG shows delta waves marked with red arrows:

Treatment:

  • Catheter ablation is the treatment of choice.
  • Anti-arrhythmic drugs like procainamide, amiodarone, quinidine, propafenone, dofetilide are used in slowing conduction in the accessory pathway (prolong refractory period).
  • IV procainamide is the drug of choice in a hemodynamically stable WPW presenting with atrial fibrillation.
  • DC cardioversion is done in hemodynamically unstable patients.

questions.text: A patient presents to you with palpitations and a heart rate of 150/minute. An ECG is done which is shown below. If the blood pressure is normal, what is the next best step in the management of this patient?

choices.text: Administer IV dihydropyridine calcium channel blocker

questions.solution:
The ECG showing sawtooth flutter waves along with the clinical scenario suggests a diagnosis of atrial flutter. The next best step is to administer an intravenous (IV) beta-blocker for rate control as the patient is hemodynamically stable.

The initial management of atrial flutter targets rate control through IV atrioventricular (AV) nodal blocking agents. These include beta-blockers or non-dihydropyridine calcium channel blockers (CCB) such as verapamil and diltiazem. Intravenous ibutilide, a class III antiarrhythmic agent can be used for rhythm control.

If the patient presents with severe symptoms or is hemodynamically unstable, electrical cardioversion is the first step. If the episode duration is > 48 hours, or if the patient has an increased risk of thromboembolic stroke based on the CHAD2DS2 -VASc scoring system, anticoagulation must be provided before the cardioversion. The drugs which can be used are direct oral anticoagulants (DOAC) such as apixaban, edoxaban, and rivaroxaban. Dabigatran, an antithrombin inhibitor, and warfarin, a vitamin K antagonist can also be used. 

The first episode does not warrant the continuation of antiarrhythmic drugs after conversion to sinus rhythm. In recurrent episodes, sotalol or amiodarone may be used.

At least 4 weeks of anticoagulation therapy is carried out after electrical or chemical cardioversion, as done in atrial fibrillation. Patients with risk factors for thromboembolism should continue it for longer. The definitive treatment is catheter ablation for recurrent cases.

The ECG shows characteristic sawtooth flutter waves due to the atrial activity in the inferior leads ( leads II, III, and aVF). Positive P waves are seen in lead V1. Conduction of more than 230 impulses/ minute through the AV node is not possible in adults. Hence a 2:1 or greater AV block is almost always associated. So patients present with tachycardia of 130-150 beats/minute. Typically, the atrial rate is around 240-300/minute.

Atrial flutter is more commonly seen in patients with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease or structural heart disease. Symptoms include palpitations, dizziness, and fatigue.

Related Pearl: Supraventricular tachycardias

 

Supraventricular tachycardias with narrow QRS complex:

  • Narrow QRS with regular RR interval
   Tachycardia                ECG features
Sinus tachycardia Normal P wave, normal ECG features except for the rate
Focal atrial tachycardia A single type of abnormal p wave morphology is seen
Junctional tachycardia No p waves. Heart rate is 100- 200/ min
AV nodal reentry tachycardia No p waves. Pseudo R' waves may be seen. Heart rate is 150-250/ min
Atrioventricular reentry tachycardia P wave always follows QRS. RP interval< PR interval
Atrial flutter Sawtooth shaped flutter waves are seen

 

  • Narrow QRS with irregular RR interval
     Tachycardia        ECG features
Atrial fibrillation No distinct p waves seen
Multifocal atrial tachycardia More than 3 different abnormal p wave morphologies are seen
Atrial flutter/tachycardia with variable block ECG features of heart block are seen.

 

Supraventricular tachycardias with wide QRS complex:

  • Antidromic AVRT (atrioventricular reentry tachycardia)
  • Supraventricular tachycardias with bundle branch block

questions.text: A patient presented to the ER with dizziness and palpitations. ECG is shown below. Which of the following drugs cannot be used in this condition?
questions.solution:
The scenario and ECG findings (absent P waves and RR intervals that are irregularly irregular) are suggestive of atrial fibrillation. Lignocaine is not used in atrial arrhythmias. 

Lignocaine is a class 1B anti-arrhythmic agent. It blocks Na+ channels mostly in the closed/inactivated state. It is not used in atrial arrhythmias because the atrial action potential is so short that the Na+ channels are in a closed/ inactivated state for only a brief amount of time.

Lignocaine is used in the acute treatment of ventricular tachycardia and ventricular fibrillation.

Drugs mostly used for supraventricular arrhythmia are:
  • Adenosine
  • Verapamil
  • Diltiazem
  • Digoxin
Drugs used for ventricular arrhythmia are:
  • Lidocaine 
  • Mexiletine
Drugs used in both conditions are:
  • Amiodarone
  • Beta-blockers
  • Class 1a / 1c antiarrhythmics

questions.text:
A 60-year-old male patient was brought to the emergency department with palpitations and dizziness. On examination, a new onset diastolic murmur is heard in the left third intercostal space. A diagnosis of acute severe aortic regurgitation is made. Arrange the expected clinical signs in this patient from above downwards with respect to the body part affected.
  1. Landolfi’s sign
  2. Traube’s sign
  3. Muller’s sign
  4. Rosenbach’s sign
questions.solution:
The correct answer is option B: 1-3-4-2.

Landolfi’s sign: Alternating constriction and dilation of the pupil

Muller’s sign: Systolic pulsation of the uvula

Rosenbach’s sign: Pulsation of liver

Traube’s sign: A pistol shot sound over femoral arteries
